title: Purification of mouse axoplasmic proteins from dorsal root ganglia nerves for proteomics analysis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Sciatic nerve dissection
Timing: ∼ 2 h
The steps of the sciatic nerve dissection 24 h after sciatic nerve injury are described in this section.
Sacrifice mouse by cervical dislocation 24 h after sciatic nerve injury.
Spray the entire body with 70% ethanol and remove skin and internal organs to make dissection easier.
Transfer the clean mouse body to a foam board and fix the fore and hind limbs on the board with four bent 20g needles keeping the back of the mouse onto the board.
Dissect the tissues under the dissection microscope.
Using the student vannas spring scissors, carefully cut the ventral vertebrae and expose the spinal cord using forceps.
L4-L6 sciatic DRG are located in the intervertebral foramen, carefully dissect these DRG by cutting the branches that are connected to them. Next, collect them in 1 mL 1× PBS with protease and phosphatase inhibitors in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube on ice for other experiments.
Transpose the mouse body with its back upwards and fix it on the board again.
Open the sciatic nerve wound with the hardened fine scissors and expose the injured sciatic nerve carefully with forceps.
Remove the attached tissues as well as a very thin nerve near the main branch.
Carefully grab the injured end of the proximal segment of the sciatic nerve with forceps and pull it along the spine.
Once the nerve is pulled out as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A, immediately place it in a 3.5 cm cell culture dish with 2 mL 0.2× PBS with protease and phosphatase inhibitors on ice.

Collect 10 sciatic nerves from 5 mice in one 3.5 cell culture dish, therefore preparing 2 dishes for 10 mice.
Collect sciatic nerves from animals that have received the sham injury.
Cut the nerves with the microdissection scissor in the wound site.
Pull it out carefully with forceps after tissue clearance.
The length of the nerve should be the same as that collected from the mice who had SNA injuries. The overall length is about 1.8 cm in total as shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A for an adult mouse.

Critical: Mouse should be euthanized in a fume hood to avoid allergies caused by animal hairs and taken out after skin is removed. Dissection has to be done as soon as possible after the mouse has been sacrificed. Keep the cell culture dishes on ice the whole time. Sciatic DRG must be harvested before nerve dissection for the nerves to be easily pulled out.
Dorsal root dissection
Timing: ∼ 4 h
This section describes the steps of the sciatic dorsal root dissection 24 h after spinal cord injury.
When collecting sciatic dorsal roots from mice that received a spinal cord injury or laminectomy, fix them on the foam board with their backs down.
Dissect the tissues under the dissection microscope.
Cut the ventral vertebrae using the student vannas spring scissors carefully without cutting the dorsal roots and expose the spinal cord with forceps.
Carefully dissect L4-L6 sciatic DRG out from the intervertebral foramen using forceps without breaking the roots.
Separate the dorsal from the ventral root and track along the spine until you reach the dorsal root entry zone.

Collect the dorsal root segment that extends from the DRG to the dorsal root entry zone. The L6 dorsal root is the longest (∼ 1.5cm) as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B.
Pool dorsal roots from 7 and 8 mice in one 3.5cm cell culture dish and always keep the dish on ice. Prepare 2 dishes for a total of 15 mice.
Critical: When sacrificing mice, perform cervical translocation gently without breaking the spinal cord and dorsal roots. Carefully cut and remove the ventral vertebrae as the L6 DRG dorsal root is very thin and easy to be cut off.
Axoplasm extraction
Timing: ∼ 4 h
This section explains how to extract axoplasm after tissue dissection.
Transfer the nerves to a new 3.5 cm cell culture dish with 2 mL 0.2× PBS with protease and phosphatase inhibitors.
Cut each nerve into 2 pieces. Gently expose and separate nerve fascicles under the dissection microscope with fine forceps until they become cloudy and float in the dish as shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B.
Transfer the floating fascicles to a fresh 2 mL Eppendorf tube containing 500 μL 0.2× PBS with inhibitors, keep the tube on ice. Transfer fascicles immediately after they become cloudy and start the separation on the next nerve.
Once finish, incubate the Eppendorf tube at 20°C–22°C for 2 h.
After incubation, transfer fascicles to a new 2 mL Eppendorf tube and wash them with 1 mL 0.2× PBS with inhibitors. Wash 5 min on the roller mixer.
Repeat the washing steps 2 more times.
After washing, transfer the fascicles into a new empty 2 mL Eppendorf tube to remove liquid, repeat this step once.
Transfer the fascicles to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube containing 300 μL 1× PBS with protease and phosphatase inhibitors and incubate at 20°C–22°C for 30 min.

Pre-cool the centrifuge to 4°C during incubation, centrifuge at 10,000×g for 10 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube, the total volume is about 500 μL.
The axoplasm is ready for concentration.
Critical: Complete the fascicles separation as soon as possible. In the final incubation step (step 15), pool fascicles from the sciatic nerve (10 mice) or from the dorsal roots (15 mice) to one 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: Stop here for the first day and store the axoplasm at 4°C for up to 72 h or proceed to the next concentration step.
Axoplasm concentration and buffer exchange
Timing: ∼ 4 h
This section describes the steps of axoplasm concentration and buffer exchange before mass spectrometry.
Prepare the Amicon® Pro device by attaching the Amicon® Ultra-0.5 filter to the base of the exchange device.
Add 500 μL TBST with 1% Tween20 to the exchange device, close the cap and centrifuge at 4,000×g for 1 min at 4°C.
Add 500 μL 1× PBS with inhibitors to the exchange device, close the cap and centrifuge at 4,000×g for 1 min at 4°C.
Remove the Amicon® Ultra-0.5 filter and place a 2 mL Eppendorf tube over top and invert. Centrifuge at 1,000×g for 2 min at 4°C.
Add purified axoplasm to the exchange device and centrifuge 4,000×g for 30 min at 4°C in a swinging bucket rotor.
After sample concentration, add 500 μL denaturation buffer to the exchange device. Centrifuge at 4,000×g for 2 h at 4°C. The final volume should be about 30 μL.
Remove the Amicon® Ultra-0.5 filter and place a collection tube which is provided in the Purification System over the top and invert. Centrifuge at 1,000×g for 2 min at 4°C.

Store the concentrated samples at −80°C for the Mass Spectrometry analysis.
Critical: In step 23, after 2 h centrifugation, check sample volume, if the volume is more than 30 μL, increase the centrifuge time until the final volume is about 30 μL. In step 24, when removing the Amicon® Ultra-0.5 filter from the exchange device, depress the cap at the same time to expel the remaining sample that is held by the exchange device tip into the filter.
Pause point: Stop here. Proceed to the mass spectrometry experiment after collecting the axoplasm samples from all the groups.
Mass spectrometry sample preparation
Timing: ∼ 1 day
This section describes the steps of axoplasm protein sample preparation for mass spectrometry.
Heat the axoplasm samples at 70°C for 10 min in 1× NuPAGE LDS Sample Buffer with 100 mM DTT. 20 ug protein is loaded per sample.
After, separate proteins on 10% NuPAGE Bis-Tris gel in MES running buffer for 10 min at 180 V.
Fix the gel in 7% acetic acid containing 40% methanol for 15 min.
Stain the gel using the Colloidal Blue Staining Kit for 30 min.
After staining, cut the lanes containing proteins from the gel.
Chop the gel slices and collect them in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube. Incubate with 1 mL 50% ethanol in 25 mM NH4HCO3 at 20°C–22°C with rotating followed by several rounds of exchange until destained.
Remove destain buffer, dehydrate the gel pieces in 100% acetonitrile for 10 min with rotating until they are white and compact.
Remove the supernatant, dry sample gel pieces with the vacuum (using Vacuum centrifuge).
Rehydrate and reduce the vacuum-dried samples in 150 μL reduction buffer (10 mM DTT in 50 mM NH4HCO3, pH 8.0) for 60 min at 56°C.

Remove buffer, add 150 μL 50 mM iodoacetamide in 50 mM NH4HCO3, pH 8.0 and incubate at dark for 45 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash gel pieces once in 50 mM triethylammonium bicarbonate buffer, pH 8.0.
Remove the solution and repeat steps 32 and 33, then add 160 μL trypsin digestion buffer (1 μg trypsin per sample in 50 mM triethylammonium bicarbonate buffer, pH 8.0) and incubate 1–12 h at 37°C.
Critical: Remove all acetonitrile before trypsinization to ensure the complete digestion of proteins.
Peptides extraction, purification, and desalting
Timing: ∼ 1 day
Peptides are extracted, purified, and desalted in this section.
Collect the supernatant which contains the protein peptides to a new Eppendorf tube.
Add 100 μL 30% acetonitrile extraction solution to the gel pieces and incubate for 15 min at 20°C–22°C with shaking at 1,400 rpm.
Collect the supernatant and combine it with the solution obtained in step 38.
Repeat steps 39 and 40.
Add 100 μL 100% acetonitrile and incubate at 20°C–22°C for 15 min with sharking at 1,400 rpm.
Collect the supernatant and combine it with the previous supernatant.
Repeat steps 42 and 43.
Reduce supernatant volume with vacuum to remove acetonitrile until ∼100 μL is left.
Perform reductive methylation labeling for quantification as described previously (Hsu et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
After labeling, purify peptides using C18 StageTips as described in (Rappsilber et al., 2007[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]).
Activate and equilibrate C18 material with 50 μL each 100% methanol, 80% acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid and 0.1% formic acid before loading peptides.
Load peptides supernatant.
Wash with 0.1% formic acid.
Elute the peptides in 30 μL 80% acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid and dry it with vacuum.
Reconstitute peptides in 14 μL of 0.1% formic acid.

Load 3.5 μL peptides for liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry analyses. For detailed parameters of HPLC and mass spectrometer used for this study, please refer to our publication (Kong et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
Critical: Reductive methylation labeling can only be performed in the absence of ammonium ions which is given when using triethylammonium bicarbonate. It also provides buffering conditions to restrict the labeling reaction in a pH range of 5-8.5.
Mass spectrometry analyses
Timing: ∼ 1 day
This section describes the steps of mass spectrometry analysis.
For peptides identification and protein quantification, perform a database search using MaxQuant Version 1.5.2.8 (Cox and Mann, 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]) against the Mus musculus Ensembl database (release-81; 3 July 2015; 53,819 entries).
Apply the following settings and thresholds:
Variable modification: acetyl (protein N-term), oxidation (M).
Fixed modifications: carbamidomethyl (C).
Apply FDR < 0.1 for the peptides and protein analyses.
Set dimethylLys0 and dimethylNter0 as light labels and dimethylLys4 and dimethylNter4 as heavy labels, these are set with a maximum of three labeled amino acids.
Proteins with at least two unique peptides are considered as identified.
Filter out proteins identified only with peptides containing a modification.
Apply MaxQuant default settings for protein quantification.
Calculate the ratio between heavy and light using two unique peptides per protein.
Convert proteins’ Ensembl ID to gene names using the ‘biomaRt’ package.
Apply deconvolution statistical approaches to calculate the differential protein expression between injury and sham conditions. The pipeline was described in our publication (Kong et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
Critical: Ensure all settings are correct and the correct database is loaded.
